page.title: 01Sheildaig Bay and Hinterland
page.content: The block is mainly uninhabited, boggy, heather moorland, dotted with small lochs (known locally as the "Fairy Lochs") and interspersed with rocky outcrops most prominent of which is Sidhean Moor 225 feet in height. At the eastern boundary the main road to Gairloch follows the river Kerry through a steep gorge, bordered on either side by coniferous trees. The river flows through Gairloch Dam then turns notth and passes under a humped back granite bridge which connects a minor single-trach road to the main road. In the north easytern corner is the beautiful Shieldaig Bay which, with its aafe anchorages and magnificent sunsets, provides and ideal setting for a hotel catering for tourists on hunting and fishing holidays.
